SENT.plain: ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), caused by acute occlusion of the infarct-related coronary artery, is an emergency condition
The primary therapy is restoration of full antegrade flow by either percutaneus coronary intervention (PCI) or thrombolytic therapy (TT)
Although primary PCI is superior to TT in patients with STEMI, there are many limitations in clinical practice
TT decreases mortality in STEMI patients, but as experience with thrombolytic agents grows, the potential risks of serious side effects become more apparent
The major complications are bleeding, hypotension and skin rash
We report on a case of cerebrovascular accident (CVA) caused by cerebral emboli following TT
We concluded that the fact that the patient was in arterial fibrillation (AF) was a major contributing factor to her CVA
This is an extremely rare condition, and our case appears to be the second one reported on in the literature
